javax.time.temporal

Interface TemporalAdder

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    Duration, Period, SimplePeriod

    public interface TemporalAdder
    Strategy for adding to a temporal object.

    This interface is used to add the period or duration represented by this object to a temporal object. It exists to externalize the process of addition, permitting different approaches, as per the strategy design pattern.

    There are two equivalent ways of using a TemporalAdder. The first is to use this interface directly. The second is to use Temporal.plus(TemporalAdder): 

       // these two lines are equivalent, but the second approach is recommended
   dateTime = adder.addTo(dateTime);
   dateTime = dateTime.plus(adder);

    Implementation notes

    This interface must be implemented with care to ensure other classes operate correctly. All implementations that can be instantiated must be final, immutable and thread-safe.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Temporal addTo(Temporal temporal)
      Adds this object to the specified temporal object.

    • Method Detail

      • addTo

        Temporal addTo(Temporal temporal)
        Adds this object to the specified temporal object.

        This adds the period or duration represented by this object to the specified temporal object.

        There are two equivalent ways of using a TemporalAdder. The first is to use this method directly. The second is to use Temporal.plus(TemporalAdder): 

           // these two lines are equivalent, but the second approach is recommended
   dateTime = adder.addTo(dateTime);
   dateTime = dateTime.plus(adder);
        Implementation notes
        The implementation takes the input object and adds the amount represented by this object to it. For example, the implementation Duration will add the length of the duration.

        Implementations must use the methods on Temporal to make the adjustment. The returned object must have the same observable type as the input object

        The target object must not be altered by this method. Instead, an adjusted copy of the original must be returned. This provides equivalent, safe behavior for immutable and mutable implementations.

        This interface can be used by calendar systems other than ISO. Typically this requires no extra work, because the algorithm for adding in the calendar system is part of the Temporal implementation.

        Parameters:
        temporal - the temporal object to adjust, not null
        Returns:
        an object of the same type with the adjustment made, not null
        Throws:
        DateTimeException - if unable to add
        ArithmeticException - if numeric overflow occurs
